preface.title: Preface
preface.para: Apache Isis is designed to allow programmers rapidly develop domain-driven applications following the Naked Objects pattern. It is made up of a core framework that supports supports various viewers, along with APIs and implementations relating to security, the programming model, the runtime (persistence) and profile stores (user preferences). Apache Isis is hosted at the Apache Foundation, and is licensed under Apache Software License v2.

sect1.title: Who this Guide is For
sect1.para:
This guide is written for programmers looking to understand how the core framework of Apache Isis fits together, including an understanding of its core APIs. It is divided into the following parts/chapters:
Architectural Overview
The introductory chapter discusses some of the main architecture elements of the framework's design, distinguishing and explaining the reason for the applib, the core modules, the viewers, and the main APIs exposed by the core.
Chapters for each of core modules
This part of the guide goes through each of the modules that make up the core framework. We also identify the main APIs exposed by the core: security, programming models, and runtime.

We don't however describe the implementations of these APIs; for these see their respective guides. What that means is that we don't describe how to actually deploy an Isis application here, because that depends upon the runtime/viewer in use. See the relevant runtime documentation for details.

You'll also find that this guide does explain how to actually write the domain objects that make up an Isis application; for that you should look to the applib (application library) documentation. Meanwhile, the programming model documentation describe how to customize the default programming model to your own ends. However this guide does explain why Isis is architected to have an applib in the first place, and it shows what the programming model looks like inside of Isis.

sect1.title: Abbreviations used in this Guide
sect1.para:
Apache Isis is built using Maven, which identifies every module with a groupId, an artifactId, a version, and a type. These are called the Maven co-ordinates. In this guide we identify each module using notation (groupId:artifactId); you should assume that the version is the latest version, and the type is the default JAR artifact
Maven modules can create other artifacts too, such as a test JAR artifact. This would be indicated with a type of test-jar. But the default artifact is a regular JAR. . Hence (org.apache.isis:core) is the Maven module with a groupId of org.apache.isis and an artifactId of core.
As a further convenience, we use "oai" as an abbreviation for org.apache.isis. Hence (oai.runtimes:dflt) refers to the default runtime module.

In this guide we also use the "oai" abbreviation within package names. For example, oai.core.runtime.authentication.AuthenticationManager is an abbreviation of org.apache.isis.core.runtime.authentication.AuthenticationManager.

chapter.title: Architectural Overview

abstract.para: What's in this guide, it's relationship to the applib documentation.

chapter.para: Apache Isis is a full-stack open source application development framework, designed to let you rapidly develop enterprise business applications following a domain-driven philosophy. Developing an application in Isis is - at least initially - about focusing on the bit that matters to the business, the core domain logic.

sect1.title: Hexagonal Architecture
sect1.para: Apache Isis' architecture is a variant of the typical layered architecture, called the hexagonal architecture. Like the layered architecture, the hexagonal architecture distinguishes between the user interface layer, the persistence (or infrastructure) layer, and the domain layer. Apache Isis' version of this architectural style is shown below.

The viewer modules constitute the presentation layer; these are the means by which the end-user initiates an interaction with the domain objects. The interaction is not directly with the domain objects, though; instead think of the viewers as interacting through a "port" into the hexagon. The Isis framework then adapts this interaction for the domain objects. Indeed, another name for the hexagonal architecture is the "ports and adapters" architecture.

As the domain objects are called, they are likely to interact with other services. The most obvious of these is an interaction with the persistence layer, either in terms of an update to themselves or the creation/update or deletion of other objects. Again, though, this isn't direct; instead the framework mediates/adapts to the configured persistence mechanism.

Alternatively, though, the domain objects may interact with other domain services. These services are specific to the application in question, for example an email service, to publish an event, to generate a PDF, to submit an order via a SOAP web service etc. Here the framework is much less involved; it merely will automatically inject any registered domain services directly into domain objects in order that they can invoke the service.

In order to support the interactions from the viewer to the domain objects, and from the domain objects to the persistence mechanism, the framework itself also calls out to other modules. The progmodel API defines the programming conventions for the domain objects; these conventions are used to build up a metamodel. Some of these conventions depend on annotations, hence these dependency from domain objects to the applib (application library) module which defines such things. It's important to note that this is the only dependency from domain objects to the framework, meaning that the domain objects are basically pojos++. The other major API called by the framework in order to do its job is the security API, which is used for authentication and authorization.

In the diagram you'll also see mention of the "default runtime". In fact Apache Isis supports multiple runtimes. The default runtime is reasonably heavyweight implementation that supports defines a persistence API, but also has support for remoting for client/server deployments (whereby the server is configured for persistence but the client's "persistence mechanism" is in fact the proxy to the server). The default runtime also supports the concept of profilestores, allowing user preferences to be stored and retrieved by viewers. Finally, the default runtime defines a pluggable bytecode enhancement API, allowing for transparent lazy loading and object dirtying.

The default runtime is not the only runtime, however. One other runtime supported is an "embedded runtime", allowing the embedding of the Isis metamodel in any arbitrary application, for example a Maven plugin. But we also expect to develop other - full-stack but more lightweight - runtimes in the future. One such that is planned is to use CDI (JSR-299) for wiring, using JDO 3.0 for the persistence API.

sect1.title: Core Framework
sect1.para: The core of Apache Isis is, well, the core modules. These consist of a set of Maven modules grouped under a parent module whose Maven co-ordinates are (org.apache.isis:core).
Each of the core modules has a Maven co-ordinate of (org.apache.isis.core:xxx), where xxx is one of:

listitem.para: test support
The testsupport module holds helper classes to support writing unit tests in either JUnit or JMock.
commons
The commons module provides a set of common utilities and language extensions for use across the rest of the framework.
metamodel

The metamodel module defines the interfaces and classes which describe the structure of the domain objects. The most obvious use of the metamodel is by the viewer modules which use it in order to know how to render the user interface. It is also used by some of the runtime/persistence implementations.
progmodel

The progmodel module provides a set of reusable elements that are used to build up the metamodel. Some of these depend upon annotations/interfaces in the applib module, others merely define a programming convention.
runtime
The runtime module defines security API (authentication and authorization) as well as a number of other lesser APIs and implementations that are likely to be of use by most runtime implementations.
webapp
The webapp module provides a number of supporting filters, servlets and other classes for use by any webapp-based viewer.

sect1.para: These modules are covered more extensively in .

sect1.title: Core APIs
sect1.para: Across the core modules a number of key APIs are defined.

listitem.para: programming model API
The core metamodel module defines the oai.core.metamodel.progmodel.ProgrammingModel interface, which defines the rules and conventions that constitute the programming model.
security API

The core runtime module defines a security API (specifically, oai.core.runtime.authentication.AuthenticationManager and oai.core.runtime.authorization.AuthorizationManager) as well as a number of other lesser APIs and implementations that are likely to be of use by most runtime implementations.
runtime (persistence) API

The responsibility of the runtime - broadly speaking - is to perform object lifecycle management, persistence and (optionally) client/server remoting. Runtimes may also offer other services, such as user preference (or profile) management.
The runtime is not an API per-se, but rather represents the environment in which the other functionality provided by the Isis framework is called. Isis has two runtime implementations:
the default runtime (oai.core.runtimes:dflt) that supports all of the above (lifecycle, persistence, remoting and profiles).

A key part of the design of the default runtime is the oai.runtimes.dflt.runtime.context.IsisContext interface, which is used to obtain the current session
This interface is somewhat akin to HibernateUtil class used in Hibernate. .
the embedded runtime (org.apache.isis.core.runtimes:embedded), to allow the Isis metamodel to be embedded within otherwise bespoke applications, and in utilities such as Maven plugins.
The intent is that other runtimes implementations (eg using CDI, JDO 3.0 etc) will be supported in the future.

sect1.title: Viewers
sect1.para: The viewers can be thought of as the outermost layer of Isis, and calls upon the services of the core framework and the configured runtime.

At the time of writing, all viewers have a dependency on the default runtime, because this is the only runtime available. In the future we expect that this will be decoupled so that viewers can run against multiple different runtime implementations.

Slightly confusingly, the default runtime does also provide the facility to "launch" viewers, meaning that for bootstrapping purposes at least the runtime calls the viewer rather than the other way around. In order to support this, the viewer implementation must provide an implementation of the runtime's oai.runtimes.dflt.runtime.viewer.IsisViewerInstaller interface. You'll see that the DnD viewer does do this, but the Scimpi and Wicket viewers do not. However, once the viewer is "up and running", the calls are strictly from the viewer to the metamodel and runtime.

sect1.title: Maven Modules and Conventions
sect1.para: Apache Isis is a large framework consisting of multiple modules. In order to make it easier to navigate, you'll find that we've aligned Maven module Ids with package names. For example:

listitem.para: the core metamodel module is (oai.core:metamodel); all classes in this module reside in the oai.core.metamodel package (or in subpackages)
the applib module is (oai:applib); all classes in this module reside in oai.applib package (or in subpackages).

sect1.para: We have also grouped modules of the same nature/interface to have a common parent. For example:

listitem.para: (oai:viewers) is the parent of (oai.viewers:dnd) and (oai.viewers:html) modules
(oai:security) is the parent of (oai.security:dflt) and (oai.security:ldap) modules

sect1.para: There is also a top-level "parent" module, (oai:isis-parent). This is used to define common build/plugin dependencies, as well as a number of Maven profiles that can be used to build subsets of the modules, and to build the Maven website.

Finally, Isis also has an (oai:release) module. The purpose of this module is simply to define a set of Isis modules/versions that are compatible with each other and thereby constitute a release. These can be imported using:
The Isis quickstart archetype makes use of the release module in this way (as do the various examples that live in .../trunk/examples).

chapter.title: Test Support Module

abstract.para: Classes and interfaces in the oai.core.testsupport module.

chapter.para: The testsupport module holds helper classes to support writing unit tests using either JUnit or JMock. It should only ever be added as a dependency with a scope of test:

sect1.title: JMock Support
sect1.para: The classes in the oai.core.testsupport.jmock package provide convenience adapters for JMock. For example, they provide the MockFixture interface that allows mocks expectations to be managed as fixture objects in their own right (thereby making such expectations reusable across tests). They also provide subclasses of the org.jmock.Mockery class with a number of convenience methods.

sect1.title: JUnit Support
sect1.para: The classes in the oai.core.testsupport.junit package provide helper classes designed, among other things, to make it easier to write value types.

chapter.title: Commons Module

abstract.para: Classes and interfaces in the oai.core.commons module.

chapter.para: The core commons module provides a set of common utilities for use across the rest of the framework. It also defines a number of small, mostly internal, APIs.
Generally it shouldn't be necessary to add an explicit dependency to the commons module, because it will be depended upon transitively by other modules in oai.core.

sect2.title: Component and Installer API
sect2.para: Isis is a modular framework, and the Component interface (in oai.core.commons.components package) represents this abstraction. For example, an authentication manager is a Component, and so too is an adapter map (for tracking object identities).
Component has three subinterfaces to represent different scopes (or lifetimes) of component instances, namely:

listitem.para: ApplicationScopedComponent, for components that exist for the duration of the application
SessionScopedComponent , for components that are created a-new for each session, and
TransactionScopedComponent, for components that are bound to a single transaction.

sect2.para:
For webapp/server-based deployments, a session is created for each interaction
Just like JPA or Hibernate sessions. . There is typically just one transaction per session.

For client/standalone deployments, the session lasts for the duration of the application, and so is one-to-one with the application scope. For these cases a transaction is used to wrap each client/server interaction
Strictly speaking, this is a statement about how the the default runtime implementation works. Other runtimes could conceivably take a different approach. If you are only intending to use webapp-based viewers, then don't worry about it... Isis works similarly to JPA/Hibernate. .

Closely related to Component is the Installer interface, which acts as a Component factory. Each Installer provides a type (a string) and a name (also a string), and the combination of (type, name) is expected to be unique. For example, the DnD viewer has a type of "viewer" and a name of "dnd".

This (type, name) combination is used to determine the configuration files that are searched for when the Component is created. Each Component's Installer will search for at least two property files: type.properties and type_name.properties. For example, the DnD viewer will search for both viewer.properties and also viewer_dnd.properties file
In fact, it is possible for an Installer to nominate additional property files; this is sometimes appropriate where a Component does double-duty and plays more than one role. At the time of writing this capability was only used by the components that install client/server remoting for the default runtime module. . An Installer can also indicate whether a missing config file should be treated as an error or can be ignored (generally the latter).

sect2.title: IsisConfiguration and IsisConfigurationBuilder API
sect2.para: The IsisConfigurationBuilder (in oai.core.commons.config package) is used to hold the "current" configuration; as (the Installer for) Components are loaded each indicates the property file(s) to load, and these are used to update the current configuration held within IsisConfigurationBuilder. The "current" configuration is initially just the properties in the isis.properties file (see for details on where this file is actually loaded from) .

When the Component is actually instantiated, it is handed an immutable IsisConfiguration that can be thought of as a snapshot of the set of properties held by the IsisConfigurationBuilder. A consequence of this design is that different Components will have references to different IsisConfiguration objects; though all should always have access to "their" properties.

Using properties specified in the configuration files is done by get the IsisConfiguration singleton from the context and using one of the lookup methods to get a value, as the example below shows. The Configuration.ROOT constant provides the base property name ("isis."). If no value is found with the specified property name exists then null (or 0 or false) will be returned.

The ResourceStreamSource interface (in oai.core.commons.resource package) is an abstraction over locating resource files. It is used predominantly to locate configuration files (see ), with implementations to load from the config directory or from the classpath.

Different implementations of IsisConfigurationBuilder use ResourceStreamSource in order to search for config files in specific locations. In principle it would be straightforward to write a new implementation of ResourceStreamSource that loads config files from some other location (eg LDAP, the Windows registry or a database) and then write a new IsisConfigurationBuilder to use it.

sect2.title: Encoding API
sect2.para: The oai.core.commons.encoding package provides a number of classes to support the custom serialization of elements of any element:

The DataInputExtended and DataOutputExtended interfaces are straightforward extensions of java.io.DataInput and java.io.DataOutput respectively, simply adding the capability to serialize arrays of primitives. The DataInputStreamExtended and DataOutputStreamExtended implement these interfaces, providing the ability to read from/write to an underlying java.io.InputStream.

Finally, the Encodable interface defines a contract for objects to write themselves to a DataOutputStreamExtended, with an implied contract that they can be re-constructed from a corresponding DataInputStreamExtended.

The primary usage of the encoding API is to enable client/server remoting, as supported by the default runtime implementation. However, it is also used in order to create Mementos of domain objects (again, a capability of the default runtime). This is used by some viewers in order to maintain a handle on transient (not-yet-persisted) objects.

sect2.title: AuthenticationSession Definition
sect2.para: The AuthenticationSession interface (in the oai.core.commons.authentication package) provides a representation of an authenticated user within the system.

Also worth mentioning is the utility class AuthenticationSessionUtils can be used to create an oai.applib.security.UserMemento, which is the corresponding type within the applib (that is, the identity of the authenticated user as the domain objects understand it).

The interface to actually authenticate users and create AuthenticationSessions - namely AuthenticationManager - is defined in the core runtime module (see ). This shouldn't be confused with AuthenticationSessionProvider which merely returns the current AuthenticationSession if one exists.

The Debuggable interface(in the oai.core.commons.debug package) is used by some Components in order to build structured string representations of themselves for debug purposes. A good example is the debug menu options available within the DnD viewer.

sect2.title: Hamcrest Matchers
sect2.para: The IsisMatchers class (in the oai.core.commons.matchers package) provides a collection of Hamcrest Matchers for use in both tests and also production code.

sect2.title: Ensure API
sect2.para: The Ensure class (in the oai.core.commons.ensure package) allows assertions to be made about arguments, state or general context, and uses Hamcrest Matchers to express those assertions.

chapter.title: Metamodel Module

abstract.para: Classes and interfaces in the oai.core.metamodel module.

chapter.para: The core metamodel module defines the interfaces and classes that make up the Apache Isis metamodel. This metamodel is at the very heart of Isis, and used in numerous ways:

listitem.para: to provide the ability to provide XML Snapshots (through the XmlSnapshot utility class, in the core runtime module, (oai.core:runtime)).

chapter.para: In addition, the metamodel provides a mechanism for the framework and the clients of the framework to access and manipulate the domain objects by wrapping them in an adapter. This is an important point: the framework and its clients never interact with the domain objects directly.

Note however that the metamodel module does not itself define the programming model conventions; that is the responsibility of the configured programming model (the default being the one defined in the default progmodel (oai.progmodels:dflt).

sect1.title: ObjectSpecifications and the SpecificationLoader
sect1.para: To make the domain objects useful within the framework the objects' public interfaces must be exposed. Isis uses a number of techniques to do this, but the predominant one is the Java reflection APIs (in the java.lang.reflect package), a process we call introspection. These are used to determine what properties and collections an object has, what behaviour it can offer, and to find other information such as the object's title, a suggested order of its fields, and when its actions can or can't be used. It also is used to flag the type of object (abstract, lookup, object, value, and whether persistable); to refer to its superclass, any inteferfaces it implements and to list any subclasses.

The details about this interface are recorded in an instance of ObjectSpecification (in the oai.core.metamodel.spec package). As each class of domain object is loaded into the system its corresponding instance of ObjectSpecification is generated. You can think of ObjectSpecification as analogous to java.lang.Class.

sect2.title: SpecificationLoader component
sect2.para:
The specification object can be retrieved directly, by name or class, from the SpecificationLoader component
For historical reasons the SpecificationLoader component is also sometimes called the reflector; indeed ObjectReflector is a subinterface that is used internally.

. When a domain object is used within the framework the SpecificationLoader instance is asked for the ObjectSpecification of the domain object's class. The first time that a class is requested the loader is responsible for performing the introspection and creating a complete ObjectSpecification. Thereafter the specification is returned from a cache.

The set of ObjectSpecifications built up by the SpecificationLoader are all those that are reachable from the service classes (defined in isis.properties configuration file under isis.services key). Because cycles between ObjectSpecifications are permitted (that is, ClassA can reference ClassB and ClassB can reference ClassA), the creation of ObjectSpecifications is actually a two-stage process. When a class' ObjectSpecification is being created, any prerequisite specifications (for its class members) will be created if necessary, however those prerequisites will not flagged as not yet "introspected". Only when those prerequisite ObjectSpecifications are actually requested by name will their introspection be formed. This prevents infinite loops from occurring in the SpecificationLoader.
It is also possible - and common - to obtain the ObjectSpecification from the domain object's adapter (the ObjectAdapter interface, discussed in ).

sect3.title: Accessing the SpecificationLoader
sect3.para: If using the default runtime module (oai.runtimes:dflt), then the SpecificationLoader can be accessed using oai.runtimes.dflt.runtime.context.IsisContext#getSpecificationLoader(). It is an application-scoped component, meaning that a single instance is used for the duration of the application running.
Other runtime implementations will (are likely to) use dependency injection to make the SpecificationLoader available.

sect2.title: ObjectMembers
sect2.para: One of the main purposes of ObjectSpecification is to describe the structure of the domain object to which it relates, in other words the members of that object's class. These are represented by (sub-)interfaces of the ObjectMember interface (in the oai.core.metamodel.spec.feature package). The main sub-interfaces of ObjectMember are OneToOneAssociation, OneToManyAssociation and ObjectAction.

The ObjectSpecification#getProperties() method returns a list of OneToOneAssociations that represent the properties (eg Order#getShipDate() or Order#getCustomer()), while ObjectSpecification#getCollections() returns OneToManyAssociations to represent collections (eg Order#getLineItems()). Properties and collections are typically rendered in some sort of form within a viewer. Any remaining public methods (eg Order#cancel()) are represented as actions, accessible using ObjectSpecification#getActions() and returning a list of ObjectActions. These are typically rendered as menu items or links in viewers.

The OneToOneAssociation, OneToManyAssociation and ObjectAction interfaces all provide the ability to interact with the underlying domain object, allowing viewers to determine whether the property/collection/action is visible, is enabled/disabled, and whether a new value/argument is valid.

It is also possible to obtain individual class members. For example, an individual property can be accessed via the getProperty(String) method, where the sole parameter is the the identifier of the property. In the case of a property, its identifier will be the name of the property method with the get prefix removed, and the first character of the remaining string converted to lowercase, so getCustomerId() become customerId. A similar pattern is used for collections, while actions have an identifier that also takes into account the parameters. In fact, the rules for constructing identifiers are available within the applib, in the oai.applib.Identifier class.

The complete list of properties/collections/actions is used for things like persistence and remoting, however user interfaces need to consider what properties they show to avoid making hidden or unauthorised properties visible. To selectively get hold of all associations (properties and collections) the getAssociations(Filter<ObjectAssociation>) method should be used
Rather than reinvent a filter API, the core framework reuses the applib's oai.applib.filter.Filter<T> class , allowing us to set up a search filter based on any criteria that might be relevant. Typically views are created using only dynamically visible properties (so hidden fields are not visible and do not have any screen space reserved form them). However, in the case of a table the view will require a column for each potentially available (statically visible) property has a column created for it, but only show a value in the cell if the property is visible for the object in question (dynamically visible). To support this, two useful predefined instances are the available: ObjectAssociationFilters.STATICALLY_VISIBLE_ASSOCIATIONS and the ObjectAssociationFilters.dynamicallyVisible(ObjectAdapter) factory method.

sect1.title: How the metamodel is built up internally
sect1.para: As already explained, the SpecificationLoader is responsible for building up completed ObjectSpecifications, one for each class that is reachable within the domain model. Moreover to avoid cyclic dependencies, these ObjectSpecifications are built-up in two stages; initially they are created but not fully built (introspected); only when required does introspection take place.
This section goes into some of the internals as to how introspection process works.

sect2.title: FacetFactorys and Facets
sect2.para: The first thing that Isis does is to create a FacetedMethodsBuilder for each ObjectSpecification. This is a helper object that co-ordinates the identification of the object members (ie the properties, collections and actions) of the ObjectSpecification. Each such object member is represented as a FacetedMethod. You can think of this as analogous to java.lang.reflect.Method, and it does indeed wrap an instance of such a Method. We'll get onto the "faceted" part of that name in just a minute.

The actual hard work of building up the metamodel, though, is done by a collection of FacetFactorys. Each FacetFactory is responsible for understanding a specific element of the programming model. For example, one FacetFactory looks for the disableXxx() method that is used to disable (grey out) an object member, another looks for @Hidden that will hide an object member, another looks for @RegEx that can be used to validate property proposed values or action parameter arguments. Each of these pieces of knowledge is represented as a Facet, and is attached to the corresponding FacetedMethod (hence its name).

If you explore the type hierarchy then you'll see that FacetMethod implements FacetHolder, and it is this interface through which the FacetFactorys work. You might also note that ObjectSpecification also implements FacetHolder, as does FacetedMethodParameter, which represents an action parameter. What that means is that FacetFactorys can also add Facets to these other types too. The interface for FacetFactory reflects this, having methods to handle the processing of a class, a method and an action parameter. All of these can have Facets.

To summarize: the Isis metamodel has a type that is equivalent to a java.lang.Class (ObjectSpecification), to a java.lang.reflect.Method (FacetedMethod) and to an action parameter (FacetedMethodParameter). Each of these can have a set of Facets attached to it, and these Facets are the metadata for each such element.

sect2.title: Identifying object members
sect2.para: Recall that the FacetedMethodsBuilder is responsible for co-ordinating the building of the FacetMethods of its owning ObjectSpecification. The first step involves identifying the actual properties, collections and actions of that ObjectSpecification (based on the underlying java.lang.Class). To do this, the FacetedMethodsBuilder searches the set of FacetFactorys for a factory that implements the PropertyOrCollectionIdentifyingFacetFactory. From these two collections of FacetedMethods are created, one set to represent the properties and the other to represent the collections.
Once all properties and collections have been identified, all remaining public methods are assumed to be actions. These form a third set of FacetedMethods.

sect2.title: Ordering Members (MemberLayoutArranger)
sect2.para: The FacetedMethodsBuilder's job is done once all the FacetedMethods have been identified. At this point, the ObjectSpecification takes over and completes the job of building itself. The first task is to re-order the identified members (still in the form of FacetMethods). It does this by delegating to a MemberLayoutArranger which is used returns the members in the required order.

note.para: The current implementation of MemberLayoutArranger orders the members as per the @MemberOrder annotation. In the future this component may take responsibility for more sophisticated layout arranger, to handle column-based layouts. This will require a change to its API.

sect2.title: Creating ObjectMembers (wrapping FacetedMethods)
sect2.para: After the FacetedMethods have been ordered, they are then wrapped in the appropriate subclass of ObjectMember (already discussed, see ), in other words as a OneToOneAssociation, OneToManyAssociation or as an ObjectAction. These objects provide a number of methods that allow the clients of the metamodel (eg specifically, viewers) to interact with underlying domain objects (see ) through the metamodel.

sect2.title: Decorating Facets (FacetDecorator)
sect2.para: The last major step of building the metamodel is to decorate any Facets, using any registered FacetDecorators. Decorated Facets allow additional behaviour to be added to already identified Facets, and so are useful for adding internationalization and (in the client/server remoting support provided by the default runtime), transactional control.
FacetDecorators are specified as a comma-separated list in the isis.properties configuration file using the isis.reflector.facet-decorators key. For example:
will install a FacetDecorator for internationalization that loads from a java.util.ResourceBundle.
The core FacetDecorator implementations are in the core progmodel module (see ).

note.para: The FacetDecorator design actually predates use of Facets within the Isis metamodel (we renamed it to FacetDecorator after the fact). If you dig into the Facet API you'll see that it supports the concept of an underlying Facet (Facet#getUnderlyingFacet()). At some stage we hope to remove FacetDecorators completely and simply use the underlying Facet approach.

sect1.title: MetaModel Validation (MetaModelValidator)
sect1.para:
After all ObjectSpecifications have been identified and loaded, the SpecificationLoader calls out to the configured MetaModelValidator (defined in the org.apache.isis.core.metamodel.specloader.validator package). This provides the ability to validate that all loaded types are valid. Precisely what "valid" means depends on the context; the default MetaModelValidator is a no-op. However, some plug-in modules for Isis might provide their own rules. For example, the JPA object store
Note that at the time of writing the JPA object store was part of Isis, having originally been written as a sister project for the Naked Objects framework. requires that all domain objects that are annotated with javax.jpa.Entity provide an "id" property annotated with javax.jpa.Identifier. Or, you might wish to configure your own MetaModelValidator in order to enforce your own project-specific rules.
The MetaModelValidator can be specified using the isis.reflector.validator key. For example:
will install com.mycompany.myproj.isis.MyMetaModelValidator as the MetaModelValidator.

sect1.title: ProgrammingModel API
sect1.para: As will be apparent from , the set of conventions that make up the programming model is determined by the set of FacetFactorys that are used to process each class as it is loaded by the SpecificationLoader.

The ProgrammingModel (in the org.apache.isis.core.metamodel.progmodel package) class is used to define this set of FacetFactorys, and is looked up right at the beginning of the bootstrap process when the SpecificationLoader is being specified. The default ProgrammingModel is defined in the default progmodel [oai.progmodels:dflt] module, and corresponds to the set of conventions described in the applib documentation.

You may have occasion when you want to modify the ProgrammingModel. For example, suppose you wanted to support a new annotation, for example @StringLengthBetween(3, 10) annotation intended to be applied to string properties and parameters. This would require a corresponding StringLengthBetweenFacetFactory. This FacetFactory would then need to be added to the ProgrammingModel.

There are two ways in which you can register this new FacetFactory. The first is to create your own ProgrammingModel (typically by subclassing the default ProgrammingModel) and then call its #addFactory(Class<? extends FacetFactory>) method. Your new implementation should then be registered in the isis.properties configuration file using the isis.reflector.facets key:
will install com.mycompany.myproj.isis.MyProgrammingModel as the MetaModelValidator.

Alternatively, if you are just tweaking the default ProgrammingModel, then you can simply use isis.reflector.facets.include and isis.reflector.facets.exclude keys to include/exclude facets. The value for each of these keys is a comma-separated list:

note.para: Isis' support for Groovy works by defining a custom ProgrammingModel.

sect1.title: ObjectAdapters
sect1.para: Isis wraps each domain object in an ObjectAdapter (in the oai.core.metamodel.adapter package). The rest of the framework does not normally work with the domain objects directly, but via these adapters. This is typically done by asking the ObjectAdapter for its corresponding ObjectSpecification by way of its #getSpecification() method. This allows the viewers to query the state of the object. For example the statement adapter.getSpecification().getProperties().get(0).get(adapter) would retrieve the first value of the first property of the domain object held by the Isis referenced by adapter.
The adapter also exposes facilities to allow the runtime to manage the lifecycle of the wrapped domain object.

listitem.para: the #getOid() method is used to return a unique object identifier (an instance of the Oid class in the org.apache.isis.core.metamodel.adapter.oid package)
This is an abstraction over a primary key, because it is guaranteed to also be unique for non-persisted objects (if the runtime supports non-persisted objects; the default runtime does)
the #getVersion() returns version information about the domain object through a Version object
This allowing runtimes to implement optimistic locking
the #getResolveState() state returning lazy loaded state, via the ResolveSate object
This allows runtimes to know whether the datastore needs to be queried to bring back additional data as the user "walks the object graph".

sect1.para: The Oid class in particular warrants further discussion.

sect2.title: Object Identifiers (Oids)
sect2.para: An Oid is an object identifier for every domain entity, and is typically assigned by the runtime. For persisted objects it is value is assigned by the object store, but for transient objects (if the configured runtime supports them) the framework will also assign an Oid, and will manage its mutation if the object changes its persistence state (from transient to persisted, or vice versa).

This Oid is used to uniquely reference the same object either across space (client/server remoting calls between VMs) or across time (between a sequence of requests to a webapp, say). The Oid is unique and that means that the runtime can maintain a one-to-one mapping to the ObjectAdapter, and hence to the wrapped a domain object.
Mapping the Oid to ObjectAdapter is an example of the identity map pattern. In the case of the default runtime [oai.runtimes:dflt], the mapping is actually both from Oid --> ObjectAdapter, and from domain object pojo --> ObjectAdapter. (The ObjectAdapter has references to its Oid and wrapped domain object pojo, so this makes both of these implicitly bidirectional mappings). Typically an Oid is also immutable, however its value may change if an object changes its persistence state. In this case the runtime is required to ensure that all mappings that it might hold (eg from Oid to ObjectAdapter) are correctly maintained. To support this the previous state of the Oid is copied so that getPrevious() now returns a copy of the original Oid (instead of null) and hasPrevious() will return true.

note.para: This feature is used by the default runtime's [oai.runtimes:dflt] client/server remoting module. When an Oid with a previous value is persisted, the client-side runtime uses the previous Oid to obtain the original tranisent object from its local cache. The object is then removed from the cache, its Oid is updated (via the copyFrom(Oid) method) and then it is returned to the cache. The results in the newly persisted object having the new persistent Oid and it being accessible as such from the cache. At this point the original version's transient state will no longer be recognised.

sect3.title: Entity (owned) Collections
sect3.para: When an domain object is an entity that has a scalar reference to another object (eg, an Order has an associated Customer) then the referenced pojo (Customer) will be wrapped in its own ObjectAdapter. This is the usual, normal, case, as described above.

When a domain object is an entity that has a vector reference to another object (eg an Order has a collection of OrderItems), there is another object to consider: the instance of List<?> (eg ArrayList<OrderItem>) that is "owned" by the owning entity (Order).

An ObjectAdapter is created for this owned List<?> also, but its Oid is of type AggregatedOid, and its identity its kept synchronized with its parent. This is done by way of the AggregatedOid#getParentOid() method.

sect3.title: Values
sect3.para: Although values (such as Strings, or ints) are also wrapped in ObjectAdapter, these always have a null Oid. Instead, the ResolveState (as described in ) is used to distinguish values and deal with them appropriately.

sect2.title: Optimistic Locking (Versions)
sect2.para: In addition to an Oid, every ObjectAdapter also references a Version which represents the object at a particular point in time. Calling ObjectAdapter#checkLock(Version) allows the adapter to check the Version it holds internally against the provided Version; if they are different then it will throw a ConcurrencyException.

The #checkVersion() method is intended to be called by server-side runtimes that either cache ObjectAdapters between calls (either server-side in a HttpSession, say, or passed up from a client-side runtime). The typical process is that the server-side code will retrieve/recreate the cached object, and then will compare it with the current version of the domain object as retrieved from the database/object store. If there is a mismatch, then the configured viewer is expected to handle the thrown exception, eg by refreshing the view and prompting the user to retry.

sect2.title: Lazy Loading (ResolveState)
sect2.para: The ResolveState class (in the org.apache.isis.core.metamodel.adapter package) is used by the ObjectAdapter to track the state of the objects references by the underlying domain object. These states form a state machine by which the framework can request to resolve objects from the database/persistence mechanism if required.
The exact states available depend on the nature of the ObjectAdapter, that is whether it represents a regular domain entity, a value, or an owned collection (List<?>) of an entity:

listitem.para: NEW - just instantiated. All ResolveStates start in this object.
TRANSIENT - a not-yet persisted object. The corresponding Oid of the ObjectAdapter should also indicate that the object is transient (Oid#isTransient()).
GHOST - a persisted object whose state has not yet been resolved (ie retrieved from the database/object store)
PART_RESOLVED - a persisted object whose properties are resolved but some of the collections are not.
RESOLVED - a persisted object all of whose properties and collections have been resolved

RESOLVING - a short-lived state on the way to RESOLVED; any changes made to the object while in this state are ignored because they are likely to be the result of an object store rehydrating the object's properties/collections
RESOLVING_PART - a short-lived state on the way to PART_RESOLVED; same rationale as RESOLVING
UPDATING - a short-lived state while the object is being updated, eg as the result of invoking an action.

DESTROYED - a object that has now been removed from the database and so is no longer considered persistent
The intent (at some stage) is to combine DESTROYED with TRANSIENT, so the object simply switches from persisted and not-persisted
SERIALIZING_GHOST, SERIALIZING_GHOST_PART_RESOLVED, SERIALIZING_RESOLVED, SERIALIZING_TRANSIENT - states for the adapter while it is being serialized, typically for remoting purposes
VALUE - the state of a value (all other states relate to entities or to entity collections)

sect2.para: The diagram below shows the state transitions supported by ResolveState:

In the case of the default runtime, the transition between these states is typically managed by the bytecode modules (cglib or javassist). These generate proxies that will automatically trigger the resolving of properties/collections if required (based on the ResolveState).

sect1.title: Interacting with domain objects (InteractionAdvisor)
sect1.para: One of the main responsibilities of the Isis viewers is to interact with the domain objects and to render them in generic (or customized) OOUIs. This involves an interplay between the ObjectAdapter (that holds the domain object) and the ObjectMembers (OneToOneAssociation, OneToManyAssociation and ObjectAdapter) accessible from the ObjectAdapter's ObjectSpecification (see ).

The success or otherwise of this interaction is determined by the Facets associated with the ObjectMember, and in particular by those Facets that implement (sub-interfaces of) the InteractionAdvisor interface:

listitem.para: Facets that implement HidingInteractionAdvisor are used to determine whether the ObjectMember is visible.
If any Facet indicates that the member is invisible, then the viewer should not display that member at all.
Facets that implement DisablingInteractionAdvisor are used to determine whether the ObjectMember is disabled.
If any Facet indicates that the member is disable, then the viewer should disable (typically: grey out) that member in the UI.
Facets that implement ValidatingInteractionAdvisor are used to determine whether the proposed modification to/through the ObjectMember is valid or not.
For a property, this means validating whether the proposed new value for that property is valid, or if the request is to clear the property, it means validating that the property may be set to null.
For a collection, this means validating whether the proposed object can be add to the collection (or removed from the collection).
For an action, this means validating that each argument is valid, and that the argument set as a whole is valid.

sect1.para:
It doesn't matter to the viewer whether the Facet (that is, InteractionAdvisor) vetoing the interaction is because of an annotation (eg @MaxLength) or a method call (eg validatePlaceOrder(...)), they are all checked in the same way
The InteractionUtils class is used internally by the ObjectMembers to check that none of the Facets attached that are also InteractionAdvisors veto the request. This can be a good place to add a breakpoint if you want to see Isis in action at close quarters. .

chapter.title: Conventions
chapter.para: The Isis framework provides a number of tools to help resolve problems and debug the system. These are mainly applicable to issues within system code, but some of them can be useful when developing applications. The framework provides the following:-

In addition, the DnD viewer provides debug views that display details of components and anything else that implements the DebugInfo interface. There is further coverage of this last feature in the DnD viewer's documentation.

sect1.title: Logging
sect1.para: Logging using Log4j is used throughout the framework and the components the Isis development team have created, and it is recommended that you use it too. Logging allows you to look what the framework and components have been when you investigate a problem and help to identify what parts of the system where doing what before an problem arose. Often logging alone is enough to pin point a problem, but if not it help you target what to investigate.

Log4j allows you to log log debug messages, information about the system's state, warnings and errors. These events can be displayed on the console, written to files, or sent out over the network for remote logging. These are output in a user defined format and also can be filtered (so only events from certain components are seen). All this is configured through a set of properties passed to Log4J.

sect2.title: Configuring Logging
sect2.para: The complete options for outputting and formatting can be found in the relavent Log4J documentation (including the API). However, it crucial to smooth development of an NOF system that will cover some of it here. The NOF configures Log4j using properties files and will generally load log4j.properties or retrieve the properties from the that were loaded from isis.properties after that is loaded for framework configuration (these files need to be located in the working directory). If you are not using classes within the NOF to start the framework then how these properties are loaded could vary. The downside of putting the logging properities in the framework properties files is that there is no logging until it has been loaded. If this is necessary then it is better to use the separate properties file.
The following file, or portion of a file, is a basic configuration for logging. It consists of two appenders and a basic logging configuration.
sect2.programlisting:
log4j.rootLogger=INFO, Console, File
# The console appender log4j.appender.Console=org.apache.log4j.ConsoleAppender log4j.appender.Console.Target=System.out log4j.appender.Console.layout=org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout log4j.appender.Console.layout.ConversionPattern=%-5r [%-20c{1} %-10t %-5p] \t\t%m%n
# The exploration.log file appender log4j.appender.File=org.apache.log4j.FileAppender log4j.appender.File.File=exploration.log log4j.appender.File.layout=org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout log4j.appender.File.layout.ConversionPattern=%-4r %-5p [%t] %37c %3x - %m%n log4j.appender.File.Append=false
sect2.para: The first line sets up logging to show events of level INFO and above through the Console and File appenders, which writes those events to the console and the file exploration.log respectively. The two blocks sepcifiy how to write to the console and the file. Other appenders can be used to change where the logs are written to. The number of appenders specified is unlimited, although there should be at least one. The console below (from Eclipse) shows the log. The file will contain the same thing although the formatting will be slightly different as the conversion pattern for the two appenders is different.

sect3.title: Logging levels
sect3.para: The types of events that are logged can be changed. This determines how large the files become or how much traffic is put over the network, and is reflected in the amount of processing that needs to be done to process the events into messages that can be written out. Levels in order of increasing verbosity and log size, and is decreasing order of severity are:-

listitem.para: OFF - no logging
FATAL - something very serious has happened that requires the system to be shut down.
ERROR - something serious has happened that might affect any subsequent actions.
WARN - something has not been set up properly, or needs attention. Although subsequent action might function correctly, they might not function as expected.
INFO - information to the developer about something that has taken place.
DEBUG - detailed information for the developer.

sect3.para: So in the above example to increase the logging level to debug change the first part of the property to DEBUG from INFO as below:

Logging should almost never be set to off, but should at least be set to log the errors (unsing level ERROR). Whilst developing we recommend that you set your basic level to INFO and switch to DEBUG if you need to investigate something.

Setting the logging level via the properties file applies that level at startup and cannot be changed using the properties, ie, that level will be used to filter all logged event while the system is running. If you are using the Skylark viewer, however, you can use the debug options to change the logging level on the client at any time. By using Ctrl-Shift-right-click on the desktop you will be shown the debug menu and see the following options:-
The greyed-out option indicates the current level. Selectiing one of the other levels will change the logging to that level.

sect3.title: Limiting logging by class
sect3.para: As well as limiting the level of events that are logged, we can also specify which classes we are interested in capturing log events for. In Log4j events are organised by loggers, which are set up programmatically, but as we create a logger for each class we talk about classes.

To change the levels of events captured according to the class where the log event was created we can class based requirements after the root logger is specified. To set a logging level for a class add a property in the form
sect3.programlisting: log4j.logger.<package to log>=<level for package> log4j.logger.<class to log>=<level for class>
sect3.para: will capture warning and errors for all classes (as defined by the root logger), and information messages for those classes whose package begins with org.apache.isis.object. In addition those classes beginning with org.apache.isis.object.reflect or org.apache.isis.object.persistence will have their debug events captured as well. Finally, the class ObjectLoader will have all of its events ignored.

It is important to make use of this feature when using the Skylark viewer as it logs events about it rendering. In Java rendering the screen (via the paint(Graphics) method) happens very often and can cause the logs to be swamped with superflous events. The logger for these events are prepended with the text 'ui.' so we can disable all of these events across all the viewing classes by adding the following to the properties:

sect3.title: Writing XML log files
sect3.para: By writing out the logs to a file in XML rather than as text allows you to look at the log using Chainsaw, a Log4j viewer. This tool allows you to quickly look at events in specific classes and hide events that are of no interest by setting up simple conditions.
To write out an XML file the same appender as before is used, but the layout is changed. The following configuration logs all events (DEBUG and greater) to a file with an XML layout.

sect3.title: Writing HTML log files
sect3.para: HTML files can be viewed in a web browser and will display nicely in most email clients. Change the appender to use the HTMLLayout class.

sect2.title: Using logging to get help
sect2.para: When you are working with someone else it is often useful to send details of what is happening including screenshots, code, and logs. To make the other person's life easier provide as much information as possible:

listitem.para: Detail the version of the framework and the platform (Java or .Net) you are using
Describe the problem in detail
Provide screenshots (as a .gif or .png, avoid jpegs and Word documents) that shows the problem
Provide log files from both the client and the server in an XML format so they can be viewed using Chainsaw
Include your contact details, preferrably you email address

sect2.para: Collate all this information ensuring each file is clearly named. Then zip up (or tar) the whole set (as the logs, in particular, can be huge) and email the compressed file.

sect2.title: Adding logging to your code
sect2.para: It is recommended that you also add logging to your code, particularly if you are developing a component or extending the framework in some way. This way you will be able to see the interaction of your classes with those of the NOF. The following lays out how the framework uses Log4j, and hence how you should use it to be consistent.

Simple ensure that any class that does any logging makes a Logger available. By convention the name is always LOG. The name of the logger should be the name of the class in its fully qualified form. To make this easy use the constructor that takes a Class object and pass in your class using as shown here. Don't forget to add an import to org.apache.log4j.Logger, not the class of the same name in the NOF or in Java itself.
sect2.programlisting: private final static Logger LOG = Logger.getLogger(IsisClass.class);
sect2.para: Where you wish to add log message add a statement like the following, deciding first what level the event should be classified as (see above); the available methods are debug, info, warn, error and fatal.
sect2.programlisting:
LOG.debug("mark as dirty " + object);
LOG.error("failed to create instance of " + this, e);
sect2.para: The first statement in this example contains just a message, while the second version logs a message and, separately, the complete stack trace.

sect1.title: Adding support for internationalisation
sect1.para: All the text that appears to the user comes from the domain object model. Any literal text used within the code may be externalised, and localised using the standard Java mechanism of resource bundles. However as all field and menu names are derived from the method names the framework provides a mechanism to adapt these names using resource bundles as well.

sect2.title: Localisation files
sect2.para: Create a file for each required language, e.g., i18n_en_GB.properties for English in Great Britain, and place them into the project such that they will be included in the class path. For the project structures we have already seen the files could be added to the resources directory, as the following example shows.
The following example is part of one of those translation file and shows how property and action names and descriptions may be specified.

sect2.title: Configuration
sect2.para: The reflector needs to be decorated with a facet decorator to look up the translated names every time the framework needs information about the fields and menus. To include the decorator add the following to a properties file.

If the application is being accessed via the web (html) viewer, then the server will need to perform the localisation, so the above property should be included in one of isis.properties read by the server; if the application is being accessed by a client (e.g. the DND viewer) then the localisation will be performed within the client, and the property should be specified in one of the properties files read by the client e.g. facet-decorator_i18n.properties.
The locale will be picked up automatically from the machine on which the code is executing. You may override this by specifying the locale in a properties file.
